replies.body:
The worst part is, they have challenger players now doing their stupid "unranked to challenger" challenges, to try to prove that it's possible to get out of elo hell.
But a player like you isn't challenger level, just better than the people he gets on his team. Because it's really RNG whether you get decent teammates (or noob enemies), it's near impossible for someone in this situation to climb.

I've had games where I absolutely dumpstered the enemy laners, only to get dumpstered the next game by better player. At this point I don't even know what elo I'm in; it seems like 1 in 5 bronze players are smurfing challengers and it's a coin flip as to whether those smurfs land on my team or the other team.

I hate to break the news to you, but if it's impossible to climb, that means you're at the right level. If you can't get out of bronze, you are a bronze player. Yes, luck and variance play their parts, but a player that actually deserves to be in plat will eventually end up in plat, even if it takes a while. I know it's a blow to the ego, but most people are silver or below players.

How do you make yourself not have the 0/10 or whatever games and more of the 10/0 ones. How do you take advantage of any lead you can take. How do you help around the map. There aren't that many smurfs, it's people who are inconsistent and will play great one game and then play like a monkey the very next one. People who have insanely good games in one and then fall over completely the next regardless of the skill of the opponent. If you compare low rank to mid rank players the main difference is not going to be mechanical skill, it's there but it's not the biggest difference. The biggest difference is actually knowing how to lose gracefully, take advantage of their leads. They will still have terrible games, but you put them in low elo games and they will more than likely just solo carry the vast majority of them. All you need to do to climb is be more consistent than those around you. When you do that everything else will slowly follow

If you keep talking yourself up to be much better than the other players in your games, and it's just your teammates holding you back, you're never going to reflect on your games and decisions objectively, since in your mind you aren't the one causing you to lose a majority of your games. 
Blame an imaginary elo hell, pretend every game you lose is just because the enemy team had smurfs, say your teammates are at fault every time if you want, but at the end of the day, they're all false excuses you're using to cope with not being able to climb.

Nice, what type of game are you talking about? A single player game? It's good to know that League of Legends is a game of one real player and a bunch of AI where you can win everytime. Do you want some real numbers? A single person on a team is only 10 percent of the total influence of a League of Legends match. That's right, only 10 percent. On your team, you only control 20 percent of what goes on. That means the other 80 percent is controlled by your teammates. Even if you play a perfect match every single time, there is no guarantee that you're still going to will because you're still only 10 percent of the match.

Even a good player cannot win matches where his or her entire team is feeding. It's simply a fact. You want some other good information? Accounts with a longstanding history get placed in much more difficult matches than newer accounts. Every year I have made it to gold easily with almost a 60 percent win rate on a new account. On this account, I cannot even climb out of Silver. Hell, right now I am having a rough time climbing out of Bronze. I can guarantee however that if I made another account and played ranked on it, that I would easily once again make it back to Gold. The matchmaking is rigged, and I have years of proof regarding it. About a year after I started playing, around Season 3, I started testing the system because I knew something seemed off, and it is. New accounts get way easier matches than accounts that have many games played on them.

Your 1/8 adc that's farming all game sure as shit isn't contributing as much as your 10/0 toplaner that just destroyed top lane inhib by themselves and soloed baron.

It depends on the degree to which your team is feeding, but you're right, you _probably_ won't win a game where you whole team is hard losing. That doesn't happen every game though, and you absolutely can influence your games to win more than you lose.

New accounts get way easier matches than accounts that have many games played on them.

You don't actually have proof of that, and there's no reason for riot to do that, nor would it even really be feasible for them to. It would make the code for matchmaking a lot more complicated than it needs to be for no reason other than to screw over their long term players. With how riot's changed ranked this season, maybe you just got lucky on your other accounts and won enough to get in gold, since your early unranked mmr and lp gains are are lot more substantial than on an account that already has a lot of games played on it. 
A gold player last season isn't going to necessarily be gold this season.
